{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3548756,"name":"","username":"robojack","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/49beb7/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-05T23:29:35.776Z","cooked":"

We have been working on code for the 2025 robot on an older machine. We recently got the coral launcher installed on the new machine and when we try to run the robot, the launch motor starts chattering. We’ve changed sparkMaxes and radios to see if it’s RFI from the new radio, double checked the wiring connections and probably some other things I can’t recall right now. After grasping at a few more straws, we tried another (same) motor to see if it happened with it. Just holding the motor, everything was fine so we then touched the metal frame of the new motor to the chassis and it started chattering just like the mounted one. The launch chassis is connected to the base with bolts but it seems that the robot drive motors are isolated from the chassis through the drive gearboxes. It appears that there is some sort of ground loop/grounding problem with the coral launch motor.

Has anybody seen this problem? It seems like there was a general rule about nothing connected to/through the chassis but the coral motor seems to violate this.

I don’t travel with the group so I can’t play with it until next week when they get back. The coach is going to ask around when they get to the competition but I thought I’d ask here to see if anybody has ideas.

Thanks for any thoughts

Use a multimeter and check for a frame short. If this reads under 120 ohms, its illegal and needs to be fixed, but slightly higher resistances may cause issues while not being completely illegal.
